items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message: The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high, but currently falling, following an extremely wet November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, the car park at Tesco and Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minor flood impacts are expected in Barnham. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes should slowly fall all week. However, through Shripney and Bersted minor flood impacts will still continue until the weekend. It will likely take a fortnight of dry weather for river levels to return nearer to normal. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We continue to routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 01/12/2022.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the weekend.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 30/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Great Somerford river gauge and there is no further rainfall forecast over the next 5 days. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Thursday,01/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.01 m and is currently stable. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.15 m and is slowly falling by 4 mm an hour. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m. We are continuing to pump at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station. Dry weather is forecast for the next five days from today, Wednesday 30/11/2022. This flood alert remains in force due to water on the moors but with the dry weather, the situation will improve. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of banks and spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 01/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to remain high in the Lower Dorset Frome as a result of the heavy rainfall at the weekend.  River levels are starting to fall but still pose a flood risk.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Friday, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.29 m and stable. Water enters Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45 m, but this is unlikely with the continuing dry weather. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.60 m and is falling by approximately 9 mm per hour. We are currently pumping to reduce the water in the moor as quickly as possible. Cutts Road is now open. Dry weather is forecast for the next five days from today, Wednesday 30/11/2022. This flood alert remains in force due to significant water still on the moor but with the dry weather, the situation will improve. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of the spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 01/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the lower part of the River Cherwell as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Thrupp. There is no rain forecast for today, Wednesday. We expect river levels to remain high for the next couple of days.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock. This is as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Water may remain on roads and farmland however further flooding is not expected for the next 24 hours. There is no rain forecast for today, Wednesday. We expect river levels to remain high on the river Glyme over the next few days. 
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated on this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain out of banks especially in the areas around Islip however water levels have been steadily falling. There is no rain forecast for today, Wednesday.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 01/12/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to remain high at the Briantspuddle river gauge on the River Piddle as a result of the heavy rainfall over the weekend.  River levels are starting to fall but still pose a flood risk between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Friday, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Leach as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain high especially in the areas around Lechlade.  There is no rain forecast for today, Wednesday. 
We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries in the Oxford area
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels along the Thames have begun falling and we no longer expect water to be out of banks. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We are expecting mostly dry weather for the next few days. 
We continue to monitor the situation. We are operating weirs to maintain river levels. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
Flood water has been observed on the Welney Causeway. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes, including the causeway at Welney. We are closely monitoring the situation and are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.

Please take caution when driving on the causeway and avoid driving through flood water. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in some places than others. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/12/22, or as the situation changes.
